[[Marxism-Leninism]] | country = Angola |split = [[Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda]] |position = [[Far-left]] }} '''Communist Committee of Cabinda''' ({{lang-pt|'''Comité Comunista de Cabinda'''}}) was a militant separatist group fighting for the independence of [[Cabinda (province)|Cabinda]] from [[Angola]]. The CCC was led by [[Kaya Mohamed Yay]] and [[Geraldo Pedro]]. It split off from the [[Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda]][http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/flec.htm Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda (Frente para a Libertação do Enclave de Cabinda--FLEC)] Global Security in 1988. ==See also== *[[Angolan Civil War]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:African and Black nationalist organizations in Africa]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Angola]] [[Category:Cold War in Africa]] [[Category:Communist parties in Angola]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations]] [[Category:Rebel groups in Angola]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1988]] [[Category:1988 establishments in Angola]] [[Category:Political parties with year of disestablishment missing]] [[Category:National liberation movements in Africa]] {{Angola-party-stub}}

{{Infobox political party | name = Cross-Community Labour Alternative |logo = |colorcode = {{Cross-Community Labour Alternative/meta/color}} |leader = |foundation = |ideology = [[Democratic socialism]]
[[Trade unionism]]
[[Nonsectarianism]]
[[Eco-socialism]]{{cite web|url=http://labouralternative.org/programme/ |title=What Labour Alternative Stand For |publisher=Cross Community Labour Alternative |date=2016-02-25 |accessdate=2016-02-25}} |headquarters = |international = |website = http://labouralternative.org/ |country = Northern Ireland |dissolution = |newspaper = |youth_wing = |membership_year = |membership = |position = [[Left-wing]] |european = |europarl = |colours = {{colour box|{{Cross-Community Labour Alternative/meta/color}}}} |seats1_title = [[Northern Ireland Assembly|NI Assembly]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|90|hex={{Cross-Community Labour Alternative/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[Local government in Northern Ireland|NI Local Councils]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|462|hex={{Cross-Community Labour Alternative/meta/color}}}} }} '''Cross-Community Labour Alternative''' is a minor political party founded to contest the [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2016]]. It stood three candidates{{cite web|author=Alex Kane |url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/independent-voices-deserve-to-be-heard-and-can-make-a-difference-1-7359934 |title=Independent voices deserve to be heard, and can make a difference |publisher=Newsletter.co.uk |date=2016-05-02 |accessdate=2016-07-29}} in the [[Belfast East (Assembly constituency)|East Belfast]], [[Belfast South (Assembly constituency)|South Belfast]] and [[East Antrim (Assembly constituency)|East Antrim]] constituencies. It was initiated by the [[Socialist Party (Ireland)|Socialist Party]].http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/articles/24162/04-01-2017/northern-ireland-cash-for-ash-scam-shows-need-for-non-sectarian-socialist-politics ==Election results== ===Northern Irish Assembly=== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%" |- !Election !Votes !Share of votes !Seats !align=center |Note(s) |- | align=center|[[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2016|2016]] | align=center|1,939 | align=center|0.3% | align=center|{{Composition bar|0|108|{{Labour Party in Northern Ireland/meta/color}}}} | align=left|#13 |- | align=center|[[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2017|2017]] | align=center|2,009 | align=center|0.3% | align=center|{{Composition bar|0|90|{{Labour Party in Northern Ireland/meta/color}}}} | align=left|#11 |- |} In the 2016 Assembly election, Cross-Community Labour Alternative reached 1939 first-preference votes standing 3 candidates. The party's Conor Sheridan polled 551 first preference votes (1.7%) in East Antrim.,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/politics/northern-ireland-constituencies/N06000005 |title=East Antrim - Northern Ireland Assembly constituency - Election 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=2016-05-07 |accessdate=2016-07-29}} Sean Burns got 871 first preferences (2.7%) in Belfast South{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/politics/northern-ireland-constituencies/N06000003 |title=Belfast South - Northern Ireland Assembly constituency - Election 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=2016-05-07 |accessdate=2016-07-29}} and Courtney Robinson got 517 first preferences (1.4%) in Belfast East.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/politics/northern-ireland-constituencies/N06000001 |title=Belfast East - Northern Ireland Assembly constituency - Election 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=2016-05-07 |accessdate=2016-07-29}} In the [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2017|2017 election]] the CCLA stood four candidates, in the same three constituencies as before, and also in [[Fermanagh and South Tyrone (Assembly constituency)|Fermanagh and South Tyrone]].http://fermanaghherald.com/2017/02/retiring-doctors-forced-stay-crisis-deepens/ They won no seats and a slightly increased first-preference vote, with 2,009 votes (0.3%). ==References== {{reflist}} {{Political parties in Northern Ireland}} [[Category:2016 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Anti-austerity political parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2016]] [[Category:Labour parties in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Socialist parties in Ireland]] [[Category:Socialist parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Socialist Party (Ireland)]]

{{Infobox political party | colorcode = {{Democratic Awakening/meta/color}} | name = Democratic Awakening | native_name = Demokratischer Aufbruch | logo = DemokratischerAufbruch.svg | logo_size = 250px | abbreviation = DA | leader1_title = Leaders | leader1_name = [[Friedrich Schorlemmer]],
[[Rainer Eppelmann]]
[[Günter Nooke]],
[[Thomas Welz]] | foundation = October 1989 | dissolution = October 1990 | headquarters = [[East Berlin]] | newspaper = | youth_wing = | membership_year = | membership = | successor = [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democratic Union]] | ideology = [[Liberal democracy]]
[[Christian democracy]]
[[German reunification|German unionism]] | position = [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]]{{Cite book |first1=Christina |last1=Boswell |first2=Dan |last2=Dough |title=Politicizing migration: opportunity or liability for the centre-right in Germany? |editor-first=Tim |editor-last=Bale |work=Immigration and Integration Policy in Europe: Why Politics – and the Centre-Right – Matter |publisher=Routledge |year=2009 |page=21}} | national = | international = | european = | europarl = | colours = {{Color box|#000000|border=darkgray}} [[Black]] | website = | country = East Germany }} '''Democratic Awakening''' ({{lang-de|Demokratischer Aufbruch}}) was an [[East Germany|East German]] political movement and political party that was active during the [[Fall of Communism]] and in the period leading up to the [[German reunification]]. While it was a relatively minor party, it took part in the first democratically elected government in East Germany in 1990, and is especially known because future [[Chancellor of Germany]] [[Angela Merkel]] started her political career within the party. It was founded in October 1989, based on existing politically active church groups. Founding members included Wolfgang Schnur, [[Friedrich Schorlemmer]], [[Rainer Eppelmann]], [[Günter Nooke]] and [[Thomas Welz]]. The organisation became a political party on December 16/17, 1989 in [[Leipzig]]. The party convention adopted a more conservative program than some of the founding members, like Schorlemmer, were willing to bear, so they left the party. Others, like Nooke, who left some time later, resented the growing cooperation with the [[Christian Democratic Union (East Germany)|Christian Democratic Union]] (CDU) of East Germany, which had been a member of the Communist-dominated [[National Front (East Germany)|National Front]] of parties and mass organisations that had supported the Communist regime. Democratic Awakening now supported rapid [[German reunification]] and joined the [[Alliance for Germany]] (''Allianz für Deutschland'') along with the CDU and [[German Social Union (East Germany)|German Social Union]] (DSU) for the [[East German general election, 1990|1990 Volkskammer elections]] on March 18. Only a few days prior to the elections, party chairman Schnur had to confess to having been an informer for the [[Ministry for State Security (East Germany)|Ministry for State Security (Stasi)]], and resigned. Although Alliance for Germany won the elections, Democratic Awakening only collected 0.9% of votes, amounting to four seats in the Volkskammer. Eppelmann became minister for disarmament and defense in the new government and new party chairman. On August 5, 1990 Democratic Awakening ceased to exist after merging into the East German CDU, which in turn on 3 October 1990 merged into its [[West German]] counterpart, the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democratic Union]] (CDU). From February 1990, [[Angela Merkel]] served as the party's spokeswoman. After the mergers, Merkel was elected in the [[German federal election, 1990|post-unification election]] as a member of the all-German [[Bundestag]] for the CDU, and eventually became [[Chancellor of Germany]] in 2005. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Demokratischer Aufbruch|Democratic Awakening}} *[http://www.chronikderwende.de/english/term.jsp?key=E_Demokratischer+Aufbruch+%28DA%29 Democratic Awakening from ''chronik der wende''] {{GDR political parties}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Die Wende]] [[Category:Organizations of the Revolutions of 1989]] [[Category:Political parties in East Germany]] [[Category:Dissent]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1989]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1990]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Germany]] [[Category:1989 establishments in East Germany]] [[Category:1990 disestablishments in East Germany]] {{Germany-party-stub}}

{{Infobox company |name = The Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA)
{{lang|ar|هيئة كهرباء ومياه دبي}} |type = [[Utilities]] ([[Government-owned corporation|Government-owned]]) |logo = DEWA logo.png |foundation = 1 January 1992 |location_city = [[Dubai]] |location_country = [[United Arab Emirates]] |location = |locations = |key_people = Saeed Mohammed Al Tayer ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) |industry = [[Utilities|Electricity, Water and District Cooling]] | area_served = Dubai | products = Utilities | parent = | subsid = [[Emirates Central Cooling Systems Corporation]] (EMPOWER) | owner = Government | slogan = | homepage = {{URL|dewa.gov.ae/default.aspx}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA)''' ({{lang|ar|هيئة كهرباء ومياه دبي}}) is a [[public service]] [[infrastructure]] company that was founded on 1 January 1992 by [[Sheikh Maktoum bin Rashid Al Maktoum]].{{cite web|url= http://www.dewa.gov.ae/aboutus/dewahistory.aspx |title=DEWA: History|publisher=Dubai Electricity and Water Authority|accessdate=24 August 2014}} It arose from the merger of the Dubai Electricity Company and the Dubai Water Department that had been operating independently until then. These organizations were established in 1959 by [[sheikh]] [[Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum]], former ruler of [[Dubai]]. The objective of the state-run company is making available to the people of Dubai an adequate and reliable supply of electricity and water.{{cite book|last1=Wilde|first1=Felix |year=2011 |chapter=Country-specific Organizations and Authorities|title=Worldwide development of nuclear Energy|location=Hamburg |publisher=Diplomica Verlag |page=25 |isbn=9783842859647 |oclc=837778047 }} As of end of 2017, DEWA employs a workforce of over 11,000 employees and provides 796,764 customers with electricity and 705,376 customers with water.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldfutureenergysummit.com/portal/sponsorship/wfes-2014-sponsors.aspx|title=2014 World Future Energy Summit Sponsors|publisher=[[World Future Energy Summit]]|accessdate=24 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115816/http://www.worldfutureenergysummit.com/portal/sponsorship/wfes-2014-sponsors.aspx|archivedate=26 August 2014|df=}} In 2017, DEWA had an installed capacity of 10,200 MW of electricity and 470 million imperial gallons of desalinated water per day.{{cite news|url=https://www.dewa.gov.ae/en/about-dewa/about-us/dewa-publications/annual-statistics|title=DEWA Statistics 2017|last=|first=|date=22 April 2015|work=|accessdate=23 June 2018|publisher=DEWA website}} After using conventional gas-fired power plants for most of its history, DEWA has recently started to add solar power to its energy mix. After installing an initial 13 MW (DC) solar plant at the Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park in 2013,{{cite web|title=DEWA 13 Solar Plant|url= http://www.firstsolar.com/en/About-Us/Projects/DEWA-13-Solar-Plant.aspx |website=firstsolar.com|publisher=First Solar|accessdate=14 February 2016}} a further 200 MW (AC) were contracted from developer ACWA Power in January 2015.{{cite web|title=Dubai Doubling Size of Power Plant to Make Cheapest Solar Energy|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-15/acwa-power-wins-contract-to-build-dubai-solar-plant-acwa-ceo |website=bloomberg.com|publisher=Bloomberg Business|accessdate=14 February 2016|date=15 January 2015}} The latest addition to DEWA's solar portfolio will be an 800 MW solar power plant, which was started in the fall of 2015 and should be completed by 2020.{{cite news|title=DEWA announces release of Request for Proposal for 800MW 3rd phase of the Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park|url= http://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395289755171.html |accessdate=14 February 2016|agency=WAM Emirates News Agency|date=29 December 2015}} DEWA plans a 250 MW [[pumped-storage hydroelectricity]] at [[Hatta, United Arab Emirates|Hatta]] using 880 million gallons of water 300 meter above a lower dam.{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/12/23/dubai-to-build-persian-gulfs-first-hydroelectric-plant-880-million-gallon-battery/ |title=Dubai to build Persian Gulf’s first hydroelectric plant, 880 million gallon ‘battery’|date=23 December 2016|work=Electrek |accessdate=24 December 2016}} == See also == {{Portal|United Arab Emirates|Energy}} *[[Energy in the United Arab Emirates]] *[[Solar power in the United Arab Emirates]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|dewa.gov.ae/default.aspx}} [[Category:Companies based in Dubai]] [[Category:Electric power in the page.title: Electoral Institute for Sustainable Democracy in Africa

revision.text:
The '''Electoral Institute for Sustainable Democracy in Africa''' (former '''Electoral Institute of Southern Africa'''), or '''EISA''', is an organization founded in 1996 in [[Johannesburg]] to "promote credible elections, participatory democracy, human rights culture and the strengthening of governance institutions for the consolidation of democracy in Africa."<ref name = about>[http://www.eisa.org.za/EISA/about.htm About EISA], EISA. Accessed July 28, 2009.</ref>
==Program Areas==
According to their website programme areas that they participate in include:<ref name = about/>
*Democracy, conflict management and electoral education *Elections and political processes *[[Balloting]] and [[electoral services]] *[[Governance]] (political parties, APRM, institutions of governance and local governance) *Online Democracy Encyclopedia *Research and information (including a specialised library and in house publications)
==Funding==
EISA lists the following organizations as donors:<ref name = donors>[http://www.eisa.org.za/EISA/donors.htm Donors], EISA. Accessed July 29, 2009</ref>
*[[Belgian Government]] *[[Canadian International Development Agency|Canadian High Commission]] (CIDA) *[[Charles Stewart Mott Foundation]] *[[Conferences, Workshops and Cultural Initiatives]] (EU-CWCI) *[[Department for International Development]] (DIFD) *[[European Union]] (EU) *[[List of diplomatic missions of Finland|Finish Embassy]], Pretoria *[[Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit]] (GIZ) *[[List of diplomatic missions of Ireland|Irish Embassy]] *[[Konrad Adenauer Foundation]] (KAF) *[[list of diplomatic missions of New Zealand|New Zealand Embassy]] *[[list of diplomatic missions of Denmark|Royal Danish Embassy]] *[[Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation]] (NORAD) *[[University of Oslo|Norwegian Centre for Human Rights]] (NCHR) *[[Norwegian Institute for Human Rights]] (NIHR) *[[Open Society Foundation South Africa]] (OSF-SA) *[[Open Society Institute|Open Society Initiative]] (OSI) *[[Open Society Institute for West Africa]] (OSIWA) *[[Open Society Initiative for Southern Africa]] (OSISA) *[[Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation]] (SDC) *[[Swedish International Development Agency]] (SIDA) *[[USAID]] RCSA
==Activities== {{main|Malawian general election, 2004}} In 2004 EISA deployed an observation mission to Malawi for the presidential and legislative elections.<ref name = Mali>{{cite book| title = The power of the vote: Malawi's 2004 parliamentary and presidential elections| author = Ott, Martin | publisher = Kachere Series, 2005 |isbn = 978-99908-76-58-1| pages =296 }} Found at [https://books.google.com/books?id=4fWOAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Electoral+Institute+of+Southern+Africa%22&dq=%22Electoral+Institute+of+Southern+Africa%22&lr= Google Books]</ref>
EISA works with the [[African Union]] [[Democracy and Electoral Assistance Unit]] (DEAU).<ref name = "AU">[http://www.ifes.org/aunion.html African Union] [[IFES]], 2009. Accessed July 9, 2009.</ref> Support in 2008 was done in conjunction with [[the Carter Center]] and the [[International Foundation for Electoral Systems]] (IFES).<ref name = "AU"/>
===Kader Asmal===
When [[Kader Asmal]], a member of the ANC, accused the [[Parliament of South Africa]] of wasting money by not monitoring [[chapter nine institutions]] such as the [[South African Human Rights Commission]] and the [[Commission for Gender Equality]], EISA hosted the conference.<ref name = corrup>MATABOGE, MMANALEDI [http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-07-20-asmal-takes-on-parliament Asmal takes on Parliament], Mail and Guardian, July 20, 2009. Accessed July 29, 2009.</ref>

[[Direct democracy]]
[[Anti-globalization movement|Alter-globalization]]
[[Feminism]]
[[Anticapitalism]]
[[Proletarian internationalism|Internationalism]] |headquarters = |international = |website = [http://www.encontroirmandinho.org/ encontroirmandinho.org] {{Gl icon}} |country = Spain |native_name = |general_coordinator= |slogan = |founded = {{start date|2007}} |dissolved = |youth_wing = Mocidade Irmandiña |membership_year = |membership = |position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] |national = [[Anova-Nationalist Brotherhood]] |european = |europarl = |affiliation1_title = Trade union affiliation |affiliation1 = [[Confederación Intersindical Galega]] |student_wing = [[Galician Student League]] (LEG) |colors = |symbol = |state = Galicia }} '''Encontro Irmandiño''' ('''EI''', ''[[Irmandiño]] Meeting'' in English) is a [[political organization]] that is part of [[Anova-Nationalist Brotherhood]] in Galicia, Spain. It used to be an internal current in the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]] (BNG). EI was founded in 2007 and has an ideology based in [[Galician nationalism]], [[direct democracy]], [[anticapitalism]], [[feminism]] and [[Anti-globalization movement|alter-globalization]].http://www.galiciaconfidencial.com/nova/10857.html ==History== Encontro Irmandiño was founded as an internal current of the BNG on 21 July 2007http://www.galiciaconfidencial.com/nova/1927.html at a meeting in [[Santiago de Compostela]]. Led by [[Xosé Manuel Beiras]],http://www.laopinioncoruna.es/galicia/2011/02/20/encontro-irmandino-constituye-partido-liderato-beiras/469402.html EI advocated for a return to the founding principles of BNG, as [[Horizontalidad|assembly]]-based internal democracy and communication between the different levels of the organization. Encontro Irmadiño abandoned the BNG in 2012.http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/galicia/2012/02/13/beiras-va-tras-30-anos-bng/0003_201202G13P2991.htm?idioma=galego On 14 March 2012 the Encontro Irmandiño announced that it had begun to contact other small formations towards the creation of a common electoral platform, among which would be [[Máis Galiza]], [[Nationalist Left]], [[Espazo Ecosocialista Galego]], [[New Galician Left]], [[Galician People's Front]] (FPG), [[Communist Party of the Peoples of Spain|Communist Party of the Galician People]] (PCPG), [[Movemento pola Base]] (MpB), [[Causa Galiza]], [[Galician Workers Front]], [[Marín Nationalist Collective]] and a small section of the [[Galician Socialist Party]] of [[Vigo]].http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/galicia/2012/03/14/once-grupos-nacionalistas-abren-contactos-confluir/0003_201203G14P12991.htm?idioma=galego This platform would have the temporary name of ''New Common Project'', and would lead to new political party: [[Anova-Nationalist Brotherhood]].http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2012/03/15/galicia/1331834607.html ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.encontroirmandinho.org/ EI official website] {{Gl icon}} {{Galician nationalism |state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Encontro Irmandino}} [[Category:Alter-globalization]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2007]] [[Category:Socialist parties in Galicia (Spain)]] [[Category:Galician nationalism]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Europe]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Spain]] {{Spain-poli-stub}}

[[Image:Coal power plant Datteln 2 Crop1.png|thumb|A coal power plant in Germany. Fee and dividend will make fossil fuels – [[coal]], [[oil]], and [[gas]] – less competitive as a fuel than other options.]]
'''Fee and Dividend''' or '''Carbon Fee and Dividend''' ('''CF&D''') is a market-based mechanism for reducing the carbon emissions that help to drive [[anthropogenic climate change]]. Carbon Fee and Dividend begins with levying a progressively-rising tax on [[carbon]]-based fuels, then returning some or all of the revenue to the public as a regular energy dividend. This is intended to incentivize a shift to low-carbon energy while protecting consumers from any increases in the costs of carbon-based fuels.
Designed to maintain or improve economic vitality while speeding the transition to a [[sustainable energy]] economy, Carbon Fee and Dividend has been proposed as an alternative to emission reduction mechanisms such as [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|complex regulatory approaches]], [[Emissions trading|cap and trade]] or a straightforward [[carbon tax]]. While there is general agreement among scientists<ref>{{cite book |author=National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine |title=The Power of Change: Innovation for Development and Deployment of Increasingly Clean Electric Power Technologies |publisher=The National Academies Press |url=https://www.nap.edu/catalog/21712/the-power-of-change-innovation-for-development-and-deployment-of |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rosenberg |first1=Stacy |last2=Vedlitz |first2=Arnold |last3=Cowman |first3=Deborah |last4=Zahran |first4=Sammy |title=Climate Change: A Profile of U.S. Climate Scientists' Perspectives |journal=Climatic Change |date=August 2010 |volume=101 |issue=3-4 |pages=311-329 |doi=10.1007/s10584-009-9709-9 |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-009-9709-9 |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> and economists<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fuller |first1=Dan |last2=Geide-Stevenson |first2=Doris |title=Consensus Among Economists —An Update |journal=The Journal of Economic Education |date=14 April 2014 |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=131-146 |doi=10.1080/00220485.2014.889963 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00220485.2014.889963 |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Haab |first1=Timothy |last2=Whitehead |first2=John |title=What do Environmental and Resource Economists Think? Results from a Survey of AERE Members |date=August 30, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Do economists all favour a carbon tax? |url=http://www.economist.com/node/21529282/print |website=The Economist |publisher=The Economist Group |accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Nuccitelli |first1=Dana |title=95% consensus of expert economists: cut carbon pollution |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/jan/04/consensus-of-economists-cut-carbon-pollution |website=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=How to pay the price for carbon |journal=Nature Climate Change |date=30 July 2018 |volume=8 |doi=doi.org/10.1038/s41558-018-0256-0 |accessdate=28 November 2018} |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-018-0256-0#article-info}</ref> on the need for a carbon tax, economists are generally neutral on specific uses for the revenue, though there tends to be more support than opposition for returning the revenue as a dividend to taxpayers<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Haab |first1=Timothy |last2=Whitehead |first2=John |title=What do Environmental and Resource Economists Think? Results from a Survey of AERE Members |date=August 30, 2013}}</ref>.
==Structure== The basic structure of Carbon Fee and Dividend is as follows:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://citizensclimatelobby.org/carbon-fee-and-dividend/|title=Carbon Fee and Dividend (Citizens' Climate Lobby)|last=|first=|date=|website=citizensclimatelobby.org|publisher=|access-date=July 8, 2016}}</ref> # A fee is levied on fuels at their point of origin into the economy, such as the well, mine, or port of entry. The fee is based upon the carbon content of a given fuel, with a commonly-proposed starting point being $10–$16 per ton of carbon that would be emitted once the fuel is burned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carbontax.org/faqs/ |title=FAQs |website=Carbontax.org |date=2008-07-01 |accessdate=2016-07-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://niskanencenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/The-Conservative-Case-for-a-Carbon-Tax1.pdf|title=The Conservative Case for a Carbon Tax|last=Taylor|first=Jerry|date=March 23, 2015|website=Niskanencenter.org|publisher=|access-date=July 6, 2016}}</ref> # The fee is progressively increased, providing a steady, predictable price signal and incentivizing early transition to low-carbon energy sources and products. # A border tax adjustment is levied on imports from nations that lack their own equivalent fee on carbon. To take one example, if the United States created a carbon fee-and-dividend system, China would face the choice of paying carbon fees to the United States or creating its own internal carbon pricing system. This would leverage American economic power to incentivize carbon pricing around the world. # Some or all of the fee is returned to households as an energy dividend. Returning 100% of net fees results in a revenue-neutral carbon fee-and-dividend system; this revenue neutrality often appeals to conservatives, such as former Secretary of State George Shultz,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323611604578396401965799658|title=Why We Support a Revenue Neutral Carbon Tax|last=Shultz|first=George|date=April 7, 2013|work=The Wall Street Journal|last2=Becker|first2=Gary|access-date=July 6, 2016|via=}}</ref> who want to reduce emissions without increasing the size and funding of the federal government. In order to maximize effectiveness, the amount of the fee would be regulated based on the scientific assessments from both economic and [[climate science]] in order to balance the size and speed of fee progression.
== Analysis ==
=== Energy Modeling Forum study 2012 ===
In late-2012 the [[Energy Modeling Forum]] (EMF), coordinated by [[Stanford University]], released its EMF{{nnbsp}}29 study titled "The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy".<ref name="emf-29-website"> {{cite web | title = EMF 29: The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy | website = Energy Modeling Forum (EMF) | location = Standford, CA, USA | url = https://emf.stanford.edu/projects/emf-29-role-border-carbon-adjustment-unilateral-climate-policy | access-date = 2016-10-22 }} </ref><ref name="boehringer-etal-2012a"> <!-- note: details here based on the recommended citation in the preamble to the document --> {{cite book | last1 = Böhringer | first1 = Christoph | last2 = Rutherford | first2 = Thomas F | last3 = Balistreri | first3 = Edward J | title = The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy: Insights from a model-comparison study — Discussion Paper 2012-54 | date = October 2012 | publisher = Harvard Project on Climate Agreements | location = Cambridge, MA, USA | url = http://live.belfercenter.org/files/bohringer_dp54_v3-final.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-22 }} </ref><ref name="boehringer-etal-2012b"> {{cite journal | last1 = Böhringer | first1 = Christoph | last2 = Balistreri | first2 = Edward J | last3 = Rutherford | first3 = Thomas F | title = The role of border carbon adjustment in unilateral climate policy: overview of an Energy Modeling Forum study (EMF 29) | date = December 2012 | journal = Energy Economics | volume = 34, Supplement 2 | pages = S97–S110 | doi = 10.1016/j.eneco.2012.10.003 | issn = 0140-9883 }} </ref> It is well understood that unilateral [[climate policy]] can lead to [[Carbon leakage|emissions leakage]]. As one example, trade-exposed emissions-intensive industries may simply relocate to regions with laxer climate protection. A border carbon adjustment (BCA) program can help counter this and related effects. Under such a policy, tariffs are levied on the carbon embodied in imported goods from unregulated trading partners while the original climate protection payments for exported goods are rebated.<ref name="emf-29-website"/> The study finds that the BCA programs evaluated:<ref name="boehringer-etal-2012b"/>
* can reduce [[Carbon leakage|emissions leakage]] * yield modest gains in global [[economic efficiency]] * shift substantial costs from abating [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] counties to non-abating non-OECD countries
In light of these findings, the study recommends care when designing and implementing BCA programs.<ref name="boehringer-etal-2012b"/> Moreover, the regressive impact of shifting part of the abatement burden southward conflicts with the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] principle of common but differentiated responsibility and respective capabilities, which explicitly acknowledges that developing countries have less ability to shoulder climate protection measures.<ref name="emf-29-website"/>
=== Regional Economic Models study 2014 ===
A 2014 [[economic impact analysis]] by Regional Economic Models, Incorporated (REMI) concluded that a carbon fee that began at $10 per ton and increased by $10 per year, with all net revenue returned to households as an energy dividend, would carry substantial environmental, health, and economic benefits:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://citizensclimatelobby.org/remi-report/|title=Carbon Fee and Dividend's Economic Impact|last=|first=|date=|website=citizensclimatelobby.org|publisher=|access-date=July 8, 2016}}</ref><ref name="nystrom-and-luckow-2014"> {{cite book | first1 = Scott | last1 = Nystrom | first2 = Patrick | last2 = Luckow | title = The economic, climate, fiscal, power, and demographic impact of a national fee-and-dividend carbon tax | date = 9 June 2014 | publisher = Regional Economic Models (REMI) and Synapse Energy Economics (Synapse) | location = Washington, DC, USA | url = https://11bup83sxdss1xze1i3lpol4-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/The-Economic-Climate-Fiscal-Power-and-Demographic-Impact-of-a-National-Fee-and-Dividend-Carbon-Tax-6.9.14.pdf | access-date = September 11, 2016 }} </ref>
* CO2 emissions in the United States would decrease to 50% of 1990 levels in the first 20 years. * Over the same timespan, reductions in airborne pollution that accompanies CO2 emissions would result in 230,000 fewer premature deaths. * Regular dividend payments would stimulate the [[U.S. economy]], leading to the creation of 2.8 million jobs over baseline during the program's first two decades. * The stimulative effect was also found to positively affect national GDP, adding $70–85 billion per year for a cumulative 20-year increase of $1.375 trillion over baseline (the approximate equivalent of adding an additional year of growth during that span).
=== International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis study 2016 ===
A 2016 working paper from the [[International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis]] (IIASA) looked more narrowly at the impact of Carbon Fee and Dividend on American households during the first year.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ummel|first=Kevin|date=April 1, 2016|title=Impact of CCL’s proposed carbon fee and dividend policy: A high-resolution analysis of the financial effect on U.S. households|url=https://citizensclimatelobby.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Ummel-Impact-of-CCL-CFD-Policy-v1_4.pdf|journal=International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis working paper|volume=|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=July 8, 2016}}</ref> Due to the shorter window analyzed (which did not allow for considerations of changes to personal energy use under the policy) the paper found a smaller percentage of households benefiting from Carbon Fee and Dividend than the REMI report summarized above (53% versus approximately two-thirds in the REMI report). It also found that an additional 19% of households suffered a loss of less than 0.2% of annual income, an amount that might be experienced as effectively "breaking even" by households in the upper income quintiles most likely affected.
==Implementation==
The [[British Columbia carbon tax]] could be considered a "fee and dividend", although there are some differences.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canada.citizensclimatelobby.org/laser-talk-the-bc-carbon-tax-vs-ccls-carbon-fee-and-dividend/|title=LASER TALK: BC Carbon Tax vs Carbon Fee and Dividend - Citizens' Climate Lobby Canada|website=canada.citizensclimatelobby.org|date=April 9, 2016}}</ref> Rather than entirely or mostly being returned as a dividend to households, 73% of the carbon tax is used to reduce corporate and small business taxes. Unlike most governments, British Columbia's electricity portfolio largely consists of hydroelectric power and their energy costs, even with the tax, are lower than most countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://peoplepowerplanet.ca/british-columbia/overview-of-electricity-sector-bc/|title=Overview of Electricity Sector - PeoplePowerPlanet|work=PeoplePowerPlanet|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/industry/electricity-alternative-energy/electricity/electricity-residents/rates|title=B.C.'s Electricity Rates - Province of British Columbia|last=Mines|first=Ministry of Energy and|website=www2.gov.bc.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Country !! Region !! Year started !! Price of CO<sub>2</sub> !! Per year progression |- | [[Canada]] || [[British Columbia]] || 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcbudget.gov.bc.ca/2008/default.htm |title=Balanced Budget 2008 - Province of British Columbia |website=Bcbudget.gov.bc.ca |date=2008-02-19 |accessdate=2016-07-09}}</ref> || $10 per ton || $5 per year |} <!-- This needs sorting out before putting back into article: ==History== The originator of the method of fee and dividend is Georg Ziegler, who at its introduction in the 1980s called it RENOVA for 'Reduction of energy-demand without command and control'. A book was published in German regarding Fee and Dividend in 1992. The title when translated to English is '[https://www.amazon.de/dp/3725304440 Ecological Tax Reform: The European level and case example of Switzerland].<ref>Mauch, Samuel P; Iten, Rolf; von Weizsacker, Ernst U; Jesinghaus, Jochen - 1992</ref> -->
==Political support== Carbon Fee and Dividend is the preferred climate solution of [[Citizens Climate Lobby|Citizens' Climate Lobby]] (CCL).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://citizensclimatelobby.org/|title=Citizens Climate Lobby|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|work=Citizens Climate Lobby|accessdate=July 8, 2016}}</ref> Citizens' Climate Lobby argues that a fee-and-dividend policy will be easier to adopt and adjust than relatively complicated cap-and-trade or regulatory approaches, enabling a smooth, economically-positive transition to a low-carbon energy economy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Carbon Fee and Dividend FAQ|url=http://www.citizensclimatelobby.org/node/444|publisher=Citizens Climate Lobby|accessdate=9 July 2011}}</ref> [[James Hansen]], Director of the [[NASA]] [[Goddard Institute for Space Studies]] has frequently promoted awareness of Carbon Fee and Dividend through his writings <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rep.org/opinions/weblog/weblog10-10-11.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=April 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219194417/http://www.rep.org/opinions/weblog/weblog10-10-11.html |archivedate=February 19, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/jan/12/james-hansen-carbon-emissions|title=James Hansen rails against cap-and-trade plan in open letter|date=12 January 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London}}</ref> and frequent public appearances, as well as his position at [[Columbia University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/mailings/2010/20100425_PeoplesBill.pdf |format=PDF |title=People’s Climate Stewardship / Carbon Fee and Dividend Act of 2010 |website=Columbia.edu |accessdate=2016-07-09}}</ref>
Inspired by the market-friendly structure of Carbon Fee and Dividend, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Congressman [[Bob Inglis]] introduced H.R. 2380 (the 'Raise Wages, Cut Carbon Act of 2009')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opencongress.org/bill/111-h2380/text |title=Archived copy |accessdate=October 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023020210/http://www.opencongress.org/bill/111-h2380/text |archivedate=October 23, 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://inglis.house.gov/sections/issues/current/rnct/The%20Triple%20Win%202.pdf] {{dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref> in the U.S. House of Representatives on May 13, 2009. Congressman Inglis considers Carbon Fee and Dividend to be a solution with great potential appeal for conservatives;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2016/01/25/donald-trump-and-the-strength-of-ten-grinches/|title=Donald Trump and the Strength of Ten Grinches|last=Inglis|first=Bob|date=January 5, 2016|website=The Daily Caller|publisher=|access-date=July 8, 2016}}</ref> concerned about energy infrastructure as an issue of [[national security]], he supports Fee and Dividend as the a reliable means of reducing dependence on foreign oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/bob-inglis-climate-change-and-the-republican-party/|title=Bob Inglis: Climate Change and the Republican Party|last=Breslow|first=Jason|date=October 23, 2013|website=PBS.org|publisher=Frontline|access-date=July 8, 2016}}</ref>
Another bill partly inspired by the Fee and Dividend structure was introduced by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Congressman [[John B. Larson]] on July 16, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/114/hr3104|title=America’s Energy Security Trust Fund Act of 2015 (H.R. 3104)|website=Govtrack.us|accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref> H.R. 3104, or the “America’s Energy Security Trust Fund Act of 2015" includes a steadily rising price on carbon but uses some revenue for job retraining, and returns the remainder of revenue via a payroll tax cut rather than direct dividend payments.
On September 1, 2016 the California Assembly Joint Resolution 43, "Williams. Greenhouse gases: climate change", was filed, having passed both houses.<ref name="ajr-43"> {{cite web | title = AJR-43 Greenhouse gases: climate change | date = 1 September 2016 | website = California Legislative Information | url = https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AJR43 | access-date = September 12, 2016 }} </ref> The measure urges the United States Congress to enact a tax on carbon-based fossil fuels. The proposal is revenue-neutral, with all money collected going to the bottom 2/3 of American households. It may have difficulty passing in Congress because it would be considered a tax, but if households were to receive an equal share in the form of a dividend then the legislation should properly class as a carbon fee. Thus California's recommendation for national legislation is perhaps close to being acceptable to Congress.
A bipartisan Carbon Fee & Dividend bill was introduced in the second session of the 115th Congress of U.S. House of Representatives on November 27th, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eenews.net/assets/2018/11/26/document_gw_06.pdf|title=Text of H.R. 7173|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Co-sponsors included Rep. Ted Deutch (D-FL), Rep. Francis Rooney (R-FL), Rep. Charlie Crist (D-FL), Rep. Brian Fitzpatrick (R-PA) and Rep. John Delaney (D-MD).<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cama |first1=Timothy |last2=Green |first2=Miranda |title=Bipartisan group of lawmakers propose landmark carbon tax |url=https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/418596-bipartisan-group-of-lawmakers-propose-landmark-carbon-tax |website=The Hill |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref>

{{Orphan|date=August 2017}}
The [https://www.globalemergencyresponse.org/ Global Emergency Response Coalition] formed in 2017 in response to hunger crises affecting more than 20 million people in Nigeria, Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia and neighboring countries.
Eight of the world’s largest U.S.-based international relief organizations united to launch a joint fundraising appeal, the Hunger Relief Fund, to the American public to respond to the unprecedented hunger crisis.
The Global Emergency Response Coalition consists of [[CARE (relief agency)|CARE]], [[International Medical Corps]], [[International Rescue Committee]], [[Mercy Corps]], [[Oxfam]], [[Plan (aid organisation)|Plan International]], [[Save the Children USA|Save the Children]] and [[World Vision United States|World Vision]].
== Publicity == The coalition has been covered by ABC News.,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/charity-groups-unite-tackle-hunger-famine-horn-africa/story?id=48730185|title=Charity groups unite to tackle hunger and famine in the Horn of Africa|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2017-07-19|website=ABC News|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref> CNN,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/14/world/iyw-famine-coalition-care/index.html|title=Charities join forces to #fightfamine|last=CNN|first=Bethany Hines and Jennifer Grubb|website=CNN|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref> The Washington Post,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/global-opinions/more-than-20-million-people-are-at-risk-of-starving-to-death-will-the-world-step-up/2017/07/17/c7d7703c-6b14-11e7-b9e2-2056e768a7e5_story.html|title=More than 20 million people are at risk of starving to death. Will the world step up?|last=Board|first=Editorial|date=2017-07-17|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-07-20|last2=Board|first2=Editorial|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Devex,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kff.org/news-summary/8-international-ngos-form-global-emergency-response-coalition-to-raise-attention-funds-for-hunger-crises-worldwide/|title=8 International NGOs Form Global Emergency Response Coalition To Raise Attention, Funds For Hunger Crises Worldwide|date=2017-07-17|work=The Henry J. == Fundraising and Partners == All funds raised by the coalition are allocated to the member agencies equally, and at the discretion of each member. At least 85% of all donations will go directly to support the communities affected.
Corporate partners of the coalition include [[BlackRock]], [[PepsiCo]]., [http://www.pepsico.com/purpose/global-citizenship PepsiCo. Foundation], [[Visa Inc.|Visa]], [[Google]], [https://www.pmxagency.com/ PMX Agency], [[Porter Novelli]] and [[Twitter]].
== Background == The causes of the crisis in each country range from drought to ongoing violence, but the consequences are the same: children and their families are struggling to survive or are starving to death. They are also at increased risk of succumbing to diseases – including cholera and measles – that induce severe diarrhea and dehydration.
More than 20 million people are facing the threat of starvation in the coming months and nearly 1.4 million children are severely malnourished and at risk of death without immediate help.

{{orphan|date=December 2012}} The '''genomic epidemiological database for global identification of microorganisms''' or '''global microbial identifier (GMI) '''<ref>{{cite web|last=GMI|title=Global Microbial Identifier|url=http://www.g-m-i.org/About.aspx}}</ref> is a platform for storing [[whole genome sequencing]] (WGS) data of [[microorganisms]], for the identification of relevant [[genes]] and for the comparison of [[genomes]] to detect and track-and-trace [[infectious disease]] outbreaks and emerging [[pathogens]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schlundt|first=J|title=The time is right for a global genomic database for microorganisms|journal=Health Diplomacy Monitor|year=2011|volume=3|issue=2|pages=2–3|url=http://www.ghd-net.org/sites/default/files/Health%20Diplomacy%20Monitor%20Volume%203%20Issue%202.pdf}}</ref> The database holds two types of information: 1) genomic information of [[microorganisms]], linked to, 2) [[metadata]] of those microorganism such as [[epidemiological]] details. The database includes all genera of microorganisms: [[bacteria]], [[viruses]], [[parasites]] and [[fungi]].
== Technology ==
For [[genotype|genotyping]] of microorganisms for [[medical diagnosis]], or other purposes, scientists may use a wide variety of [[DNA profiling]] techniques, such as [[PCR]], [[PFGE]] and [[MLST]]. A complication of this broad variety of pre-WGS techniques is the difficulty to standardize between techniques, laboratories and microorganisms, which may be overcome using the complete [[DNA]] code of the genome generated by WGS techniques.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shendure|first=J|title= Next-generation DNA sequencing|journal=Nat. Biotechnol.|year=2008|volume=26|issue=10|pages=1135–1145|doi=10.1038/nbt1486|pmid=18846087}}</ref> For straight forward diagnostic identification the WGS information of a microbiological sample is fed into a global genomic database and compared using [[BLAST]] procedures to the genomes already present in the database.<ref name="X">{{cite web|title=genomic epidemiology database|url=http://www.genomicepidemiology.org/}}</ref> In addition, WGS data may be used to back calculate to the different pre-WGS genotyping methods, so previous collected valuable information is not lost.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Inouye|first=M|title=Short read sequence typing (SRST):multi-locus sequence types from short reads|journal=BMC Genomics|year=2012|volume=13|pages=388|doi=10.1186/1471-2164-13-338|pmid=22827703|pmc=3460743|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Larsen|first=MV|title=Multilocus sequence typing of total-genome-sequenced bacteria|journal=J Clin Microbiol|year=2012|volume=50|pages=1355–1366|doi=10.1128/JCM.06094-11|pmid=22238442|issue=4|pmc=3318499|display-authors=etal}}</ref> For the global microbial identifier the genomic information is coupled to a wide spectrum of metadata about the specific microbial clone and includes important clinical and [[Epidemiology|epidemiological]] information such as the global finding place(s), treatment options and [[antimicrobial resistance]], making it a general microbiological identification tool.This makes [[Personalized medicine|personalized treatment]] of microbial disease possible as well as real-time tracing systems for global surveillance of [[infectious diseases]] for [[food safety]] and serving [[human health]].
== The initiative ==
The initiative for building the database arose in 2011 and when several preconditions were met : 1) WGS has become mature and serious alternative for other genotyping techniques,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zankari|first=E|title=Genotyping using whole-genome sequencing is a realistic alternative to surveillance based on phenotypic antimicrobial susceptibility testing|journal=J Antimicrob Chemother|year=2013|pmid=23233485|doi=10.1093/jac/dks496|volume=68|issue=4|pages=771–7|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Dunne|first=WM|title= Next-generation and whole-genome sequencing in the diagnostic clinical microbiology laboratory|journal=Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis|year=2012|volume=31|issue=8|pages=1719-17126|doi=10.1007/s10096-012-1641-7|pmid=22678348|display-authors=etal}}</ref> 2) the price of WGS has started falling dramatically and in some cases below the price of traditional identifications, 3) vast amounts of [[Information technology|IT]] resources and a fast [[Internet]] have become available, and 4) there is the idea that via a cross sectoral and [[One Health]] approach infectious diseases may be better controlled.<ref>{{cite book|last=Current Topics in Microbiology and Immunology, Vol 366|title=One Health: The Human-Animal-Environment Interfaces in Emerging Infectious Diseases|year=2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-540-70961-9|pages=280|url=https://www.springer.com/biomed/virology/book/978-3-642-35845-6?detailsPage=authorsAndEditors#|editor=Mackenzie, J.S. |editor2=Jeggo, M. |editor3=Daszak, P. |editor4=Richt, J}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Wielinga, PR |author2=Schlundt, J |title=Food Safety: At the Center of a One Health Approach for Combating Zoonoses |journal=Curr Top Microbiol Immunol|year=2013|pmid=22763857|doi=10.1007/82_2012_238|pages=3–17}}</ref>
Starting the second millennium, many microbiological laboratories, as well as national health institutes, started genome sequencing projects for sequencing the infectious agents collections they had in their [[biobanks]].<ref>{{cite web|last= A summary of genomic databases|title= Bacterial genome databases|url= http://phobos.ramapo.edu/~pbagga/binf/binf_res/bioinfo_gndb_bact.htm }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last= WGS projects info by EBI|title= WGS projects|url= http://www.ebi.ac.uk/genomes/wgs.html }}</ref> Thereby generating private databases and sending model genomes to global nucleotide databases such as [[GenBank]] of the [[National Center for Biotechnology Information|NCBI]]<ref>{{cite web|last= Genome Browser NCBI|title= Genome information by organism |url= https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/browse/}}</ref> or the nucleotide database of the [[EMBL]].<ref>{{cite web|last= Genome Browser EMBL|title= Access to Completed Genomes|url= http://www.ebi.ac.uk/genomes/}}</ref> This created a wealth of genomic information and independent databases for [[List of sequenced eukaryotic genomes|eukaryotic]] as well as [[List of sequenced bacterial genomes|prokaryotic]] genomes.<ref>{{cite web|last= Microbial Genomes Database|title=MBGD|url= http://mbgd.genome.ad.jp/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Other genomic databases via EBI|url= http://www.ebi.ac.uk/2can/databases/genomic2.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last= DOE's Joint Genome Institute Integrated Microbial Genomes (IMG) |title= IMG DOEs JGI|url=http://img.jgi.doe.gov/cgi-bin/w/main.cgi}}</ref> The need to further integrate these databases and to harmonize data collection, and to link the genomic data to metadata for optimal prevention of infectious diseases, was generally recognized by the scientific community.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Aarestrup|first=F|title=Integrating Genome-based Informatics to Modernize Global Disease Monitoring, Information Sharing, and Response|journal=Emerg Infect Dis|year=2012|volume=18|issue=11|pages=e1|doi=10.3201/eid/1811.120453|pmid=23092707|pmc=3559169|display-authors=etal}}</ref> In 2011, several infectious disease control centers and other organizations took the initiative of a series of international scientific- and policy-meetings, to develop a common platform and to better understand the potentials of an interactive microbiological genomic database. The first meeting was in Brussels, September 2011,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kupferschmidt|first=K|title=Epidemiology. Outbreak detectives embrace the genome era.|journal=Science|year=2011|volume=333|issue=6051|pages=1818–1819|pmid=21960605|doi=10.1126/science.333.6051.1818}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Consensus report of an expert meeting 1-2 September 2011, Brussels, Belgium.|url=http://www.food.dtu.dk/upload/f%C3%B8devareinstituttet/food.dtu.dk/publikationer/2011/consensus%20report%20perspectives%20of%20a%20global,%20real-time.pdf}}</ref> followed by meetings in Washington (March 2012) and Copenhagen<ref>{{cite web|last=GMI|title=GMI news and events|url=http://www.globalmicrobialidentifier.org/News-and-Events }}</ref> (February 2013). In addition to experts from around the globe, Intergovernmental Organizations have been included in the action, notably the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) and the [[World Organization for Animal Health]] (OIE).
== Development plan ==
A detailed roadmap<ref>{{cite web|last=GMI|title=GMI development plan|url= http://www.globalmicrobialidentifier.org/~/media/Sites/gmi/About/roadmap-draft2.ashx }}</ref> for the development of the database was set up with the following general timeline: :2010 - 2012: Development of pilot systems.<ref name="X" /> :2011 - 2013: International structural start-up, with the formation of an international core group, analysis of the present and future landscape to build the database, and diplomacy efforts to bring the relevant groups together. :2012 - 2016: Development of a robust IT-backbone for the database, and development of novel genome analysis algorithms and software. :2017 - 2020: Construction of a global solution, including the creation of networks and regional hubs.
== Steering committee ==
Current members:
* Eric Brown, [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA), USA * Amy Cawthorne, [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), Switzerland * Jørgen Schlundt, [[Technical University of Denmark]] (DTU), Denmark. * [[David J. Lipman]], [[National Center for Biotechnology Information]] (NCBI), USA. * Alisdair Wotherspoon, [[Food Standards Agency]] (FSA), United Kingdom. * Pathom Sawanpanyalert, [[Ministry of Public Health (Thailand)|Ministry of Public Health]] (MOPH), Thailand. * David Heyman, [[Health Protection Agency]] (HPA), United Kingdom. * Marion Koopmans, [[Erasmus MC|Erasmus University Medical Center]], [[Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment]] (RIVM). * Masami T. Takeuchi, [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) * Vincenco Caporale, [[World Organization of Animal Health]] (OIE)
Former members: * Steven M. Musser, [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA), USA. * Angelik Tritscher, [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), Switzerland.

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} The term '''Growth Recession''' indicates a situation were growth is slow, but not low enough to be a technical recession, yet, unemployment increases since more jobs are lost than created.[http://www.ezonomics.com/whatis/a_growth_recession] The term was created{{When|date=July 2011}} by Dr. Solomon Fabricant (New York University, [[National Bureau of Economic Research]])<ref>[http://www.hoisingtonmgt.com/HIM2007Q3NP.pdf], Van R. Hoisington, Lacy H. Hunt, Ph.D., Hoisington Quarterly Review and Outlook Third Quarter 2007, "Growth Recession"</ref> and is recognized and cited more recently by business [[economist]]s. Note that the term also has slightly different secondary meanings including a more general one that growth is below potential. However, the more specific meaning indicates the growth is weak and insufficient to provide jobs for those entering the labor market (see the Hoisington and [[Lacy Hunt|Hunt]] reference). There may also be a third meaning referring to growth in which more jobs are actually being destroyed than created. In all cases the term indicates, Real [[GDP]] is expanding (slowly) but with job contraction, so the economy behaves or feels in many ways like a [[recession]].
A former Group Managing Director at [[Global Insight]] who is now at the [[Bureau of Economic Analysis]] uses the phrase in this quote:
{{Quote|My feeling at the time (2002-2003) was we had a recession followed by a growth recession till 03. That’s what I showed on those Global Insight recession/growth recession charts. Mike Nemeira (Chief Economist, International Council of Shopping Centers) a better expert than I am, and I debated this. He thought there was an argument for a quick full recovery then a lapse into a growth recession. There is no agreed standard for growth recession. But I would say while it looked stronger for a couple quarters, it wasn’t real strong.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}}}
[[soft landing (economics)|Soft landings]] tend to also be growth recessions but not always. If economic growth in the economy is slowing to such a point that establishment payroll growth contracts, then the soft landing is so soft it has crossed over into a Growth Recession. Both Soft Landings in the mid-1980s and 1990s qualify as for several months employment did contract. Two months in 1995 and one month in 1986.
[[Jobless recovery]], is another similar term. All jobless recoveries are by definition also growth recessions, however not all growth recessions are jobless recoveries because a growth recession can occur at any point in an [[economic cycle]], and a jobless recovery only refers to the period immediately after a recession ends.

Talk shows and other content for the site are created primarily in studios at an undisclosed location in an industrial area outside [[Austin]], Texas.{{cite news |title=A Visit to the InfoWars Studios of Alex Jones |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/a-visit-to-the-infowars-studios-of-alex-jones-a-1136654.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=December 31, 2017}} The ''InfoWars'' website receives approximately 10 million monthly visits, making its reach greater than some [[Mainstream media|mainstream news]] websites such as ''[[The Economist]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]''.{{Cite web |url=https://www.quantcast.com/infowars.com?qcLocale=en_US#trafficCard |title=Infowars.com Audience Insights – Quantcast |website=quantcast.com|access-date=December 9, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/10/28/13424848/alex-jones-infowars-prisonplanet |title=Alex Jones, Pizzagate booster and America's most famous conspiracy theorist, explained |work=Vox|access-date=December 9, 2017}} The site has regularly published [[fake news|fake stories]] which have been linked to harassment of victims.{{efn|See: ,,, etc.}} In February 2018, [[Alex Jones]], the publisher, director and owner of ''InfoWars'', was accused of discrimination and sexually harassing employees.{{Cite news |url=https://nypost.com/2018/02/28/infowars-is-a-den-of-racism-and-harassment-ex-staffers/ |title=InfoWars is a den of racism and harassment: ex-staffers |date=2018-03-01 |work=New York Post|access-date=2018-03-01 |language=en-US}} ''InfoWars'', and in particular Jones, advocate numerous [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]] particularly around purported domestic [[false flag]] operations by the [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. Government]] (which they allege include the [[9/11 conspiracy theories|9/11 attacks]] and [[Sandy Hook conspiracy theories|Sandy Hook shootings]]). InfoWars has issued retractions various times as a result of legal challenges.Jackie Wattles (May 17, 2017). [http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/17/media/alex-jones-chiobani/index.html "InfoWars' Alex Jones apologizes for saying Chobani supports 'migrant rapists'"]. CNN .David Montero (May 17, 2017). [http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-chobani-alex-jones-20170517-story.html "Alex Jones settles Chobani lawsuit and retracts comments about refugees in Twin Falls, Idaho"]. ''Los Angeles Times''. Jones has also had contentious material removed, or been suspended or banned from various social media websites, including [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[YouTube]] and [[Apple Inc.|Apple]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-44965160 "YouTube removes 'hate speech' videos from InfoWars"]. [[BBC News]].{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/07/alex-jones-slammed-with-30-day-ban-from-facebook-for-hateful-videos/|title=Alex Jones slammed with 30-day ban from Facebook for hateful videos [Update]|work=[[Ars Technica]]|access-date=2018-07-29|language=en-us}}{{cite news |last=Riley |first=Charles |url=https://money.cnn.com/2018/08/06/technology/facebook-infowars-alex-jones/index.html |title=YouTube, Apple and Facebook remove content from InfoWars and Alex Jones |work=CNN Money |date=August 6, 2018 |accessdate=August 6, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/twitter-bans-alex-jones-and-infowars-today-2018-09-06-live-updates/|title=Twitter permanently bans Alex Jones and Infowars|date=September 6, 2018|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=September 6, 2018}} InfoWars earns revenue from the sale of products pitched by Jones during the show. It has been called as much "an online store that uses Mr. Jones's commentary to move merchandise", as a media outlet.{{cite news |last1=Williamson |first1=Elizabeth |last2=Steel |first2=Emily |title=Conspiracy Theories Made Alex Jones Very Rich. They May Bring Him Down. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/07/us/politics/alex-jones-business-infowars-conspiracy.html |accessdate=September 7, 2018 |agency=The New York Times |date=September 7, 2018}} == History == [[File:Alex Jones & Paul Joseph Watson (9072625782).jpg|thumb|[[Alex Jones]] with [[Paul Joseph Watson]]]] InfoWars was created in 1999 by American [[conspiracy theorist]] Alex Jones, who remains its controlling influence.{{cite news |last=Relman |first=Eliza |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/alex-jones-bio-conspiracy-trump-megyn-kelly-2017-6 |title=How a public-access broadcaster from Austin, Texas, became a major conspiracy theorist and one of Trump's most vocal supporters |work=Business Insider |date=June 19, 2017 |accessdate=January 17, 2018}}{{Cite web |url=https://companiestx.com/company/32034156953/free-speech-systems-llc |title=Free Speech Systems, Llc |website=companiestx.com|access-date=January 6, 2018}} ''InfoWars'' features ''[[The Alex Jones Show]]'' on their broadcasts and was established as a public-access television program aired in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]] in 1999. During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], the website was promoted by bots connected to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/fbi-investigating-right-wing-sites-role-campaign-hack-article-1.3004192 |title=FBI investigating if right-wing sites had role in campaign hacks |work=Daily News|access-date=January 2, 2018 |location=New York |language=en}} In 2016, [[Paul Joseph Watson]] was hired as [[editor-at-large]].{{cite news |title=The live-streamers who are challenging traditional journalism |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/12/11/the-live-streamers-who-are-challenging-traditional-journalism |publisher=[[The New Yorkers]] |date=December 11, 2017}}{{cite news |title=Top InfoWars editor criticizes Trump after anti-Muslim tweets |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/news/362288-top-infowars-editor-criticizes-trump-after-anti-muslim-tweets |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=November 29, 2017}} In February 2017, political commentator Dr [[Jerome Corsi]] was hired as Washington bureau chief,{{cite news |title=The Conspiracy Bureau: Alex Jones Teams Up With Jerome Corsi for White House Coverage |url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/02/02/conspiracy-bureau-alex-jones-teams-jerome-corsi-white-house-coverage |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]] |date=February 2, 2017}} after InfoWars was granted a [[White House Correspondents' Association|White House]] day pass.{{cite news |title=Conspiracy outlet InfoWars was granted temporary White House press credentials |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/infowars-granted-white-house-press-credentials-2017-5 |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |date=May 22, 2017}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' has accused Corsi, who is [[Catholic]], "of being [[Islamophobic|anti-Islamic]], [[anti-Catholic]], [[anti-Semitic]] and [[homophobia|homophobic]], and of exploiting [[racism|racial prejudices]] in an attempt to 'scare white America{{'"}}.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/oct/07/uselections2008.kenya |title=Author of anti-Barack Obama book detained in Kenya |accessdate=August 2, 2008 |first=Lee |last=Glendinning |date=October 7, 2008 |work=The Guardian |location=London}} In May 2017, [[Mike Cernovich]] joined the ''InfoWars'' team as a scheduled guest host for ''The Alex Jones Show'',{{cite news |title=Mike Cernovich, conspiracy theorist praised by Trump Jr., lands InfoWars gig with Alex Jones |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/may/4/mike-cernovich-conspiracy-theorist-praised-by-trum/ |work=[[The Washington Times]] |date=May 4, 2017}} with [[CNN]] reporting the "elevation to InfoWars host represents the meteoric rise in his profile".{{cite news |title=Right-wing troll Mike Cernovich goes professional with new hosting gig at InfoWars |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/03/media/mike-cernovich-infowars-alex-jones/index.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=May 3, 2017}} In June 2017, it was announced [[Roger Stone]], a former campaign advisor for [[Donald Trump]], would be hosting his own ''InfoWars'' show "five nights a week", with an extra studio being built to accommodate his show. In March 2018, some of the biggest brands in the U.S. suspended their ads from InfoWars' YouTube channels, after CNN notified them.{{cite web |url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/03/03/technology/youtube-ads-infowars-alex-jones/index.html |title=Advertisers flee InfoWars founder Alex Jones' YouTube channel |authors=Paul P. Murphy and Gianluca Mezzofiore |date=March 3, 2018 |website=[[Money.cnn.com]] |access-date=March 4, 2018}} In July 2018, [[YouTube]] removed four of InfoWars' uploaded videos that violated its policy against [[hate speech]] and suspended posts for 90 days. Facebook also banned Jones after it determined four videos on his pages violated its community standards in July 2018. In August 2018, YouTube, Apple, and Facebook removed content from Jones and InfoWars, citing their policies against hate speech and harassment. == Structure == === Staff === The following table lists InfoWars main staff members.{{Cite web |url=https://www.infowars.com/contact/ |title=Contact " Alex Jones' Infowars: There's a war on for your mind! |website=infowars.com |access-date=December 10, 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |+Infowars staff !Name !Role |- |Alex Jones |Publisher & Director |- |[[Paul Joseph Watson]] |Editor & Staff Writer |- |Steve Watson, Adan Salazar, Kit Daniels, Mikael Thalen, Jamie White |Associate Editor & Staff Writer |- |Anthony Gucciardi |Contributing Writer |- |Rob Dew |Nightly News Director |- |David Knight, Jakari Jackson, Lee Ann McAdoo, Joe Biggs, Millie Weaver, Owen Shroyer |Reporter |- |Jon Bowne, Clifford Cunningham, Dan Lyman |Correspondent |- |[[Jerome Corsi]] |Author & Correspondent |- |Jon Rappoport, Shepard Ambellas |Contributor |} ==Business aspects== While Jones has stated, "I'm not a business guy, I'm a revolutionary", he spends much of InfoWars air time pitching health-enhancement and survivalist products to loyal viewers. As a private firm, Infowars and its affiliated companies ("a web of limited-liability companies") do not have to report make public financial statements, so that observers can only estimate its revenue and profits. Prior to 2013, Jones focused on building a "media empire".{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Seth |title=Alex Jones’s Media Empire Is a Machine Built to Sell Snake-Oil Diet Supplements |url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2017/05/how-does-alex-jones-make-money.html |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=[[New York (magazine)|''New York'' (magazine)]] |date=May 4, 2017}} By 2013, Alex Seitz-Wald of ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'' estimated that Jones was earning as much as [[USD|USD$]]10 million a year between subscriptions, web and radio advertising, and sales of DVDs, T-shirts, and other merchandise.{{cite web |last1=Sietz-Wald |first1=Alex |title=Alex Jones: Conspiracy Inc. |url=https://www.salon.com/2013/05/02/alex_jones_conspiracy_inc/ |website=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |accessdate=9 September 2018 |date=May 2, 2013}} That year, Jones changed his business model to incorporate selling proprietary dietary supplements, including one that promises to "supercharge" cognitive functions. Unlike most talk radio shows, InfoWars itself does not directly generate income. It gets no syndication fees from its syndicater GCN, no cut of the advertising that GCN sells, and it does not sell its three minutes per hour of national advertising time. The show no longer promotes its video service (though it still exists), and has not made any documentary films since 2012. Virtually all money is made by selling Jones' dietary supplements to viewers and listeners. The diet supplement products sold on Infowars are "largely produced by Dr. Edward F. Group III, a Houston [[chiropractor]] and founder of dietary-supplement-maker Global Healing Center". A lesser source of revenue for InfoWars are its "money bomb" [[telethons]], which resemble "public-radio fund drives", except that InfoWars is a for-profit institution. Charlie Warzel reports that "three former Infowars "employees told BuzzFeed News that a money bomb could easily raise $100,000 in a day".{{cite news |last1=Warzel |first1=Charlie |title=Alex Jones Just Can't Help Himself |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/charliewarzel/alex-jones-will-never-stop-being-alex-jones |website=[[BuzzFeed News]] |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] |accessdate=9 September 2018 |date=May 3, 2017}} As of 2014, "operations were bringing in more than $20 million a year in revenue ... according to testimony Mr. Jones gave in a court case". Most of his revenue in 2014 "came from the sale of products like supplements", according to records "viewed by ''[[The New York Times]]''". 2014 court proceedings also show that InfoWars was successful enough for Jones and his wife at that time to be planning to "build a swimming pool complex ... featuring a waterfall and dining cabana with a stone fireplace. Mr. Jones bought four Rolex watches in one day in 2014, and spent $40,000 on a saltwater aquarium. Assets of Jones and his wife at the time "included a $70,000 grand piano, $50,000 in firearms and $752,000 in silver, gold and precious metals". The loss of social media platforms from being banned by Facebook, YouTube, Apple, Spotify and Pinterest may have led to appeals by Jones to viewers: "The enemy wants to cut off our funding to destroy us. If you don't fund us, we'll be shut down." == Controversies == === Promotion of conspiracy theories and fake news === InfoWars disseminates various conspiracy theories, such as speaking against the [[HPV vaccine]]{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2017/4/6/15160486/alex-jones-vaccines-autism-gates-fungus-health-conspiracy-theories |title=I watched Alex Jones give his viewers health advice. Here's what I learned. |website=Vox.com|access-date=December 28, 2017}} and claiming that the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]] was part of a conspiracy.{{cite news |last1=Hayden |first1=Michael Edison |title=Alt-right conspiracy theories blame Antifa for the mass shooting in Las Vegas |url=http://www.newsweek.com/alt-right-conspiracy-theories-blame-antifa-mass-shooting-las-vegas-677075 |accessdate=February 9, 2018 |work=Newsweek |date=October 3, 2017 |language=en}} InfoWars advocates [[New World Order conspiracy theories]], [[9/11 conspiracy theories]], [[chemtrails]], conspiracy theories involving [[Bill Gates]], supposed covert government [[weather control]] programs, claims of rampant domestic [[false flag]] operations by the US Government (including 9/11) and the unsupported claim that millions voted illegally in the 2016 US presidential election.{{Cite news Mis-Infowars: 7 Bat-Sh*t Conspiracy Theories |access-date=December 30, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/who-alex-jones-his-top-five-conspiracy-theories-ahead-nbc-megyn-kelly-626633 |title=Alex Jones says 9/11, the Sandy Hook shooting and the Boston Marathon bombing were "false flag" operations |date=June 16, 2017 |work=Newsweek |access-date=December 30, 2017 |language=en}} Jones |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/09/business/media/las-vegas-massacre-infowars-conspiracy.html |title=Las Vegas Massacre Gives InfoWars More Conspiracy Fodder |last=Grynbaum |first=Michael M. [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]] "fan fiction".{{Cite news |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/news/2014-03-12/no-armed-protests-are-not-normal-in-austin/ |title=No, Armed Protests Are Not Normal in Austin |access-date=December 30, 2017 |language=en-US}} Infowars has published and promoted [[fake news]],{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/dont-get-fooled-by-these-fake-news-sites/4/ |title=Don't get fooled by these fake news sites |date=February 10, 2017}} and Jones has been accused of knowingly in his custody case |first=Rob |last=Crilly |date=April 18, 2017 |via=The Daily Telegraph}} As part of the FBI's probe into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]], Infowars was |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/fbi-breitbart-investigate-alt-right-wing-websites-fake-news-bots-donald-trump-a7641826.html |title=The FBI are 'investigating the role of Breitbart in spreading fake news with bots' |date=March 21, 2017}} From May 2014 to November 2017, InfoWars [[Plagiarism|republished articles from multiple sources without permission]],
